"We were very happy that neither of those came to fruition." --- Evan Henkel, Jr., West Salem Personal best: 800, 1:54.78. Henkel made the Class 6A state meet as a freshman leading off the third-place 4x400 relay. Last year, he made it on his own, winning the Mountain Valley district title in the 800 before finishing second at state; he also anchored the 4x400 to a fifth-place finish. European R&D review finds lagging high-tech performance despite major science investment ... the European Union funds industrial research partnerships worth billions of euros in fields such as clean aviation and hydrogen fuel cells. It also offers direct grants to tech startups, and when Horizon Europe launches next year, it plans to offer them equity investments , too. But Hans-Olaf Henkel, a former member of the European Parliament and former president of the Leibniz Association, says he's seen this all before. Though he's in favor of funding bottom-up, basic research, Henkel argues that since the 1980s, EU research programs have fundamentally been about one thing, "to catch up" in economic competitiveness, first with Japan, then the United States, and now China. Berlin study reveals 92 percent of left-wing activists live with their parents ... acts of violence carried out against property involved arson. Right-wing extremists were the targets of violence in fifteen percent of the cases. Acts of violence committed by left-wingers are on the rise in Germany. Between 2009 and 2013, left-wing political activists committed a total of 1,523 violent crimes, more than double the amount record from 2003 to 2008. Frank Henkel, a CDU politician and Interior Senator, contends that most violent crimes that are politically motivated come from the left-wing scene. Earlier this month, left-wing extremists demonstrating in the Kreuzberg district for May Day attacked a television crew from the news program Heute-Show (Today Show), as Voice of Europe reported . Historic Berlin airport could close for good in June ...  airport just outside the city limits in October after a nearly decade-long delay, the consortium running the regional airfields voted to shut Tegel for two months owing to low demand during the pandemic. "We have a temporary operations stop with the option to reopen if necessary. Whether that will happen, I can't say," Berlin government spokeswoman Eva Henkel told AFP. Officials had previously expressed doubts whether any flights will take off after mid-June from the beloved facility, with its iconic hexagon shape and highly unusual proximity to the city centre.
